{{Infobox academic | honorific_prefix = | name = Clive Selwyn Davis | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Clive Selwyn Davis (1916-2009).jpg | image_size = 300 | alt = | caption = Clive Davis, photographed after obtaining the state’s second best Leaving Certificate pass (top in mathematics, second in physics) in 1934. (Used with the courtesy of the Sam Hood Collection, Mitchell Library, State Library of New South Wales). Published in Cohen, Graeme. (2006). Counting in Australia. Halstead Press, Broadway, NSW. | birth_name = <!-- Use only if different from full/othernames --> | birth_date = {{birth date |1916|4|15}} | birth_place = [[Sydney]], [[Australia]] | death_date = {{death date and age |2009|10|29| 1916|4|15}} | death_place = | death_cause = | region = | nationality = Australian | fields = | period = | occupation = | title = | boards = <!-- Board or similar positions extraneous to main occupation --> | known_for = | spouse = | children = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | era = | language = | discipline =[[Mathematician]] | sub_discipline = <!-- Academic discipline specialist area - e.g. Sub-atomic research, 20th Century Danish specialist, Pauline research, Arcadian and Ugaritic specialist --> | movement = <!-- Should match the idiologial movement or denomination (for religious), "school" of thought etc. (e.g. "Anglican", "Postmodernist", "Socialist" or "Green" etc. --> | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = <!-- Religious denomination should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | education = | alma_mater = [[University of Sydney]], [[Trinity College, University of Cambridge]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = <!--Only those with WP articles--> | main_interests = | workplaces = <!--full-time positions only, not student positions--> | notable_works = | notable_ideas = | influences = <!--Must be referenced from a third party source--> | influenced = <!--Must be referenced from a third party source--> | awards = <!--Notable national level awards only--> | website = | footnotes = }}
'''Clive Selwyn Davis''' (15 April 1916 – 29 October 2009) was a Professor in Mathematics at the University of Queensland and veteran of World War II. He took his PhD in mathematics at the University of Cambridge, and upon his return to Australia would work to improve the study of mathematics at the University of Queensland over the next 30 years.
== Education == Clive Selwyn Davis was born in [[Sydney|Sydney, Australia]]. He and his family of four siblings lived in the [[Strathfield, New South Wales|Strathfield]] area.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url = https://www.austms.org.au/Publ/Gazette/2010/Mar10/ObitDavis.pdf|title = Obituary: Clive Selwyn Davis|date = 2010|access-date = September 9, 2015|website = Australian Mathematical Society|publisher = Australian Mathematical Society|last = Hart|first = Vincent and Matthews, Keith}}</ref> He attended Summer Hill and Homebush primary schools and then went to [[Sydney Technical High School]]. After gaining high marks in physics and mathematics in the 1934 Leaving Certificate of NSW, he enrolled at the [[University of Sydney]], at first being attached to Engineering, before transferring to Science. He took a First Class Honours degree in Mathematics in 1937, followed by First Class Honours in Physics in 1938 and a M.Sc. in 1939. After World War II, he obtained a scholarship to [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] and was awarded his PhD in number theory in 1949, under the supervision of [[Louis J. Mordell|Louis Mordell]].<ref name=":0" />
==Military == While at the University of Sydney, Davis joined the Air Squadron there in 1936, having had an early fascination with aircraft and auto-mobiles. He trained as a pilot in the [[Royal Australian Air Force Reserve]]. After completing his M.Sc. he travelled to England on a CSIR post-graduate scholarship<ref>{{Cite news|title = GOWRIE SCHOLARSHIP AWARDS ANNOUNCED|url = http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article973929|newspaper = The Argus|date = 1945-07-05|access-date = 2016-01-28|pages = 6}}</ref> to conduct research on aircraft instruments and aerodynamics at the [[Royal Aircraft Establishment]] in Farnborough, intending to return to Australia and work at the [[Defence Science and Technology Group|Aeronautical Research Laboratories]]. When World War II began, he volunteered in the [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] and served with distinction in two tours of the Middle East<ref>{{Cite book|title = "Australia's mathematicians in World War II" in Counting Australia in : the people, organisations and institutions of Australian mathematics|last = Cohen|first = Graeme L.|publisher = Halstead Press|year = 2006|isbn = 1920831398|location = https://www.austms.org.au/Counting/CAI-chapter5.pdf|pages = 141–2}}</ref> and was awarded a [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]] in 1941. He later transferred to the RAAF, and returned to Australia.
He would serve on the Air Staff of the RAAF, and was mentioned in the official war history for his role in the development of Operations Research. In the last part of the war, he commanded 103 Squadron of Liberator heavy bombers, in their operations from North Queensland and [[Papua New Guinea]]. He retired with the rank of [[Wing commander (rank)|Wing Commander]].
== Career == Davis resumes his career in mathematics after he took his PhD at Cambridge. He lectured at the [[University of Bristol]] for seven years and was then was appointed the next chair of Mathematics at the [[University of Queensland]] in 1956, following on from [[Henry Priestley (mathematician)|Henry James Priestley]] and Eugene Francis Simonds. He led the Mathematics Department there for 27 years, retiring in 1983.
Under his leadership Davis campaigned for his new Department, finding that it was at least 20 years behind other universities he had attended.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = "Post war mathematics in the older universities" in Counting Australia in: the people, organisations and institutions of Australian mathematics.|last = Cohen|first = Graeme L.|publisher = Halstead Press|year = 2006|isbn = 1920831398|location = |pages = 189–195.}}</ref> He fought for a new building for the Department, improving teaching with the introduction of a separate Honours stream, tutorial classes and recruiting new staff .<ref name=":1" /> He fought for a separate Mathematics Library, which when it was formed, was named in his honour.<ref>{{Cite web|title = EARLY HISTORY OF THE DEPARTMENT|url = http://www.numbertheory.org/uq_history/dept_history.html|website = www.numbertheory.org|access-date = 2016-01-28}}</ref> ( It was later absorbed by the Dorothy Hill Engineering and Sciences Library at UQ in 1997. His name remains attached to the collection, as does [[Dorothy Hill]] and [[Thomas Parnell (scientist)|Thomas Parnell]], whose Geology and Physics libraries respectively were absorbed by the new library.) He was a member of the University Senate for 10 years, which was then active in improving staff conditions and setting up the FSSU superannuation scheme. He served on the University Research Committee, for seven years, three as Chairman. He was President of the [[Royal Society of Queensland]] in 1966. He was Treasurer of the [[Australian Mathematical Society]] from 1956 to 1968, and its President from 1968 to 1970.<ref name=":0" />
He was a founding member of the Great Barrier Reef Committee<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Hill | first = Dorothy | date = December 1985 | title = The Great Barrier Reef Committee, 1922-82. Part II: The Last Three Decades | url = | journal = Historical Records of Australian Science |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=195–221 | doi = | pmid = | access-date = February 26, 2016 }}</ref> and [[Wildlife Preservation Society of Queensland]].
He published papers from 1945 until 1951, with his PhD being featured in [[Acta Mathematica]]. He returned to scholarly publishing in 1978.<ref name=":0" />
Davis married Antoinette "Toni" Lowing in Melbourne in 1943 and they had three children, Dinah, Penny and Julian. They later adopted a son, Robert.<ref name=":0" /> Clive Davis died in 2009
